items.standfirst: This blog is now closedNampijinpa Price accuses Liberal colleague of ‘cowardly’ conduct as Ley tries to tone down Indian migrants debateGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastNSW logging industry group calls koala national park an ‘own goal’Not everyone is happy about the Minns government’s koala park announcement. Industry body Timber NSW accused the government of valuing “politics above science and people”.“Minister [Penny] Sharpe has had her political win but we’re now calling on Premier Minns to show some compassion by making sure what is left of the industry is sustainable, diverse and equitable.For example, extending the wood supply agreements past the expiry in 2028 so they can invest in new machinery, processing equipment and encourage investment in hardwood plantations.”There is a lot of work being done, I want to reassure your viewers of that. We will deliver an energy policy with two fundamentals. That we have a stable, reliable energy grid for affordable energy for households and businesses and we play our role in reducing emissions. Continue reading...

items.title: Two boys fatally stabbed in Melbourne's west potentially victims of mistaken identity
items.standfirst: The friends were allegedly set upon by up to eight masked men in an attack which police said has the "hallmarks of a youth gang crime".
items.content: A 12-year-old boy and a 15-year-old boy killed in a suspected machete attack in Melbourne's west overnight were potentially ambushed in a case of mistaken identity.The two friends were walking from a bus stop in Cobblebank last night just before 8pm with a third friend when they were set upon by up to eight masked men in an attack which police said has the "hallmarks of a youth gang crime".Police initially believed the stabbings were the result of a targeted attack. READ MORE: Man dies after early morning shooting in Melbourne's CBDEmergency services were called to the scene where they found the 12-year-old boy.Paramedics tried to resuscitate him but he could not be saved.Victoria Police duty crime officer Graham Banks said a short time later Dau Akueng, the 15-year-old friend, was found dead nearby on Cobble Street as a result of "significant injuries consistent with being stabbed".READ MORE: Beaches closed after surfer killed in shark attackHe added the 12-year-old and Akueng were not gang members. "Both murders are linked to the same offenders," Banks said."Witness and CCTV vision shows the murders were committed by a large group of male offenders who appear to be covered with face masks."They fled the scene in a vehicle that is yet to be identified and vision shows that they were armed with machetes."While the investigation is in its early stages, police believe the attacks have "the hallmarks of a youth gang crime"."It is one of the most horrific crimes in a substantial and growing list of crimes of this nature," Banks said."Police are appealing for witnesses to come forward and that includes people who will know these offenders."Given the time of night, it will be anticipated that a number of vehicles were around that vicinity and enough of those cars will have dashcam footage.READ MORE:Teenage boy dies after 'stolen car' crashes during police pursuit "We appeal for people who will have knowledge of this crime and that will include people known to the offenders to come forward."You can do it anonymously but you can also report it formally."Banks said police would work to determine a motive for the stabbings."When we see crimes of this nature sometimes occur, there has been occasion where people have been targeted by mistaken identity," Banks said."There is potential that the offenders know these people and they've been specifically targeted as well, but there's also clearly a possibility that it's been a case of mistaken identity and that this is what has occurred." READ MORE: China criticises Australian and Canadian warships transiting Taiwan Strait The masked men are believed to be older than the victims. Akueng's father said he needed answers for his son.."This is a basketball player, he's not a criminal," Elbino Akueng said."I'm talking on behalf of my community, this is happening to us."In the last month, we have buried four kids, similar incidents keep happening, but there's no answer from police." Akueng has been remembered as a bright and talented young basketballer. Collingwood Basketball Association (CBA) general manager Trent Pearson said he was a "much-loved member" of the club."He was a highly talented player and referee with a cheerful personality who touched all those he interacted with over many years," Pearson said."Dau had a smile and confidence that were infectious and his love for basketball and being around his friends will be sorely missed.""As a club we are devastated by his passing. I've spoken today to the family and our focus now, is supporting them and our club members in coming to terms with the tragic loss of a beautiful young man."CBA vice president Duré De Winter said Dau "brightened everyone's day with his smile" and spoke of his maturity on and off the court." We are heartbroken to lose such a beautiful young man. Our thoughts and condolences go to his family and community, they are a strong and beautiful community," Winter said."We are so sorry for their loss."Police and the NSW State Emergency Service spent the night in the street gathering evidence. "The exact circumstances surrounding the deaths are still being determined but are believed to be connected," Victoria Police said in a statement earlier today."At this time police are treating it as a targeted attack and the investigation remains ongoing."Anyone with information is urged to contact Crime Stoppers on 1800 333 000.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: WA museum tells staff ‘almost all of us are guilty’ of burning fossil fuels in email defending Woodside partnership
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Climate advocates reject CEO’s claim he is ‘not qualified’ to comment on risks of gas firm’s plan to extend production to 2070Follow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastThe head of the Western Australian Museum has told staff that burning fossil fuels is something “almost all of us are guilty of in one way or another” in an email defending the institution’s renewed research partnership with Woodside.The museum’s chief executive, Alec Coles, sent the email to staff before a Woodside-sponsored August open day at the Maritime Museum – one of WA Museum’s seven locations. It came amid public criticism of the extension of the “longstanding collaboration”, in which the gas company supports the museum’s biodiversity research along the WA coastline. Continue reading...

It came amid public criticism of the extension of the “longstanding collaboration”, in which the gas company supports the museum’s biodiversity research along the WA coastline. Continue reading...

items.title: Loss of koala habitat shows ‘total failure’ of nature laws, conservationists say
items.standfirst: More habitat has been given up legally in 2025 so far than any other year since the animals were listed as threatened, analysis showsNSW locks in great koala national park and brings in immediate ban on loggingFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastMore clearing of koala habitat has been approved under Australia’s nature laws in 2025 so far than in any other year since the marsupial was listed as a threatened species, according to an analysis by the Australian Conservation Foundation.The destruction of 3,958 ha of bush approved across eight projects, including a coalmine in Queensland, equates to about four Sydney airports’ worth of clearing. Continue reading...

items.title: Body found in burning car on side of road west of Sydney
items.standfirst: Emergency services were called to the Bells Line of Road near Mount Wilson in the Blue Mountains at about 10:30am after reports a car was on fire.
items.content: Police are investigating after a body was found inside of a burning car west of Sydney.Emergency services were called to the Bells Line of Road near Mount Wilson in the Blue Mountains at about 10.30am this morning after reports a car was on fire.When the blaze was extinguished, firefighters found a body inside.READ MORE: Beaches closed, shark net removal trial paused after surfer killedThey aware unable to establish the identity of the person or the cause of the fire.A crime scene was established and investigations into the blaze have commenced, with the State Crime Command's Homicide Squad being informed of the incident.Bells Line of Road is still closed in both directions between Mt Tomah Road at Mount St and Darling Causeway at Bell.READ MORE: Two boys aged 12 and 15 stabbed to death in Melbourne's west Motorists are being told to avoid the are and use the Great Western Highway and Darling Causeway instead.Investigators are appealing to anyone with information to come forward or to contact Crime Stoppers.They are also seeking anyone with dashcam footage recorded in the area between 10am-10:45am this morning to inform police.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Freight handler dies after accident at Sydney Airport
items.standfirst: Emergency services were called to the airport in south Sydney at around 10:30am this morning after a freight handler was reportedly struck by a vehicle.
items.content: A man has died at Sydney Airport after an accident at the freight terminal.Emergency services were called to the airport in south Sydney at around 10:30am this morning after a freight handler was reportedly struck by a vehicle.Paramedics treated the man, who is believed to be in his 40s, but he died at the scene.READ MORE: Man dies after early morning shooting in Melbourne's CBDThe incident is not being treated as suspicious.Sydney Airport said they were saddened by the incident confirmed they were offering support to airlines and authorities. "Everyone at Sydney Airport is deeply saddened by the fatal incident involving an airfreight worker earlier this morning," they told 9News.com.au.READ MORE: Devastating Father's Day after man killed in shark attack at popular Sydney beach "Our thoughts are with the worker's family, friends and colleagues during this incredibly difficult time. Sydney Airport has made its support services available to all staff across the airport precinct."We are working to support the airline and relevant authorities as they investigate the incident."Worksafe NSW has been notified and a report is being prepared for the coroner.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
